page.title: 01CONSERVATION AND ECOLOGY
page.content: Woodchester Park consists of about three square kilometres of private woodland.It is a Nature Conservancy area owned partly by the N.C.A.,partly by the Forestry Commission and partly by a consortium of private owners. There is a Study Centre situated in the Park where students from schools and universities come to study Ecology. The forest is mainly fir but each block is planted with some beechwood to continue growing when the fir trees are felled. There is one listed building in the park housing a large breeding colony of the rare greater horseshoe bat. Many species of native wild animals are to be found there, especially badgers and foxes.The yellow-necked woodmouse is to be found living alongside the ordinary woodmouse.This is unique in Britain.
